image.altText: Crash

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin offers his condolences after a plane crash that authorities say killed Wagner Group chief Yevgeny Prigozhin.

title.children: Putin breaks silence after plane crash that Russia says killed Prigozhin

image.altText: Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally

items.synopsis: The 45th US president is expected to surrender to authorities in Fulton County, Georgia, over an indictment on alleged interference in the state's 2020 election results. Follow live.

title.children: Trump leaves New Jersey for Georgia to be booked over alleged election interference

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ahead of Donald Trump’s appearance at Fulton County Jail, his former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows showed up for his booking in the case. Mr Meadows, who was on the infamous call between Donald Trump and the Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger in which Trump asked for more votes to be found, is charged with two counts, racketeering and soliciting of a violation of an oath by a public officer. A Federal judge earlier rejected his request to take up that case before he was forced to surrender ahead of a deadline tomorrow and be booked in Georgia. Bond was set at the equivalent of $US100,000 ($155,000), half of the amount his former boss Donald Trump has been asked for, and soon after his booking Mr Meadows’s mugshot was released.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mark Meadows hands himself in

props.alt: A man in a blue suit mugshot

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Trump caravan has been seen leaving New Jersey bound for Georgia.

image.altText: A close-up of a penguin chick

items.synopsis: Thousands of baby emperor penguins drowned last year in Antarctica as sea ice broke up early and reached record lows, British researchers say, reinforcing dire predictions about the future survival of the species.

title.children: Thousands of baby emperor penguins drowned in Antarctica last year. Scientists say it's 'a sign of things to come'

image.altText: A yellow bus with a sign reading not in service in front of sandstone buildings.

items.synopsis: Metro Tasmania has been struggling with a driver shortage for some time, but in recent days the number of cancelled services in Hobart has blown out. To increase reliability, Metro is scrapping some services indefinitely.

title.children: How do you make a bus service more reliable? Run fewer buses

image.altText: Two people, one wearing a mask, stand dockside next to a large ship

items.synopsis: Australia's half-billion dollar icebreaker is based in Hobart, but will have to sail to the other end of Tasmania to refuel, due to it not being allowed under a bridge in its home port — the latest setback for the trouble-prone vessel.

title.children: Authorities deem new icebreaker unsafe to pass under Tasman Bridge, meaning 700km trip to refuel

image.altText: The polluted air captured in the Monas monument in Jakarta on 11 August 2023.

items.synopsis: Jakarta residents dealing with some of the worst air quality in the world are told to wear masks and work from home, with some contemplating moving to Bali.

title.children: Masks and working from home are back in Jakarta — but not because of COVID-19

image.altText: A man and a woman holding a portrait of their son in his bedroom.

items.synopsis: Rules about who can access posthumous sperm retrieval are ethically complex. It doesn't help that, across Australia, they're also inconsistent.

title.children: These Israeli parents want to use their dead son's sperm to make a grandchild. Could it happen here?

image.altText: A woman wearing a white collared waistcoat sits in an auditorium crowd

items.synopsis: Yang Huiyan is the mysterious majority stakeholder of a sprawling real estate empire in China, but in a stunning reversal of fortune triggered by the country's ongoing property market woes, she is now locked in a desperate battle to prevent its collapse.

title.children: One of China’s richest women is an elusive billionaire heiress. Her fortune was just cut in half

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in a courtyard at parliament house.

items.synopsis: The government is failing to convincingly explain the "unusual" decision to not let Qatar Airways expand in Australia at the same time that Treasurer Jim Chalmers is launching a review into competition policy, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: The case for more flights seems open and shut. The Albanese government has questions to answer

image.altText: A woman with dark hair and a red and black checked jacket sits in a glass bus shelter in front of a garden bed.

items.synopsis: One frustrated commuter summed up the imminent slashing of bus services in Hobart by saying "public transport is something you'd expect in a reasonable sized city … apparently we can't do that".

title.children: Capital city bus operator slashes services to cope with driver shortage

image.altText: Matildas players cheer reacting to a penalty shoot out in a large stadium

items.synopsis: They may not have won their home Women's World Cup, but in performing the way they did, the Matildas have achieved something far greater than silverware.

title.children: 'I told you so': Matildas' World Cup heroics have won Australian football's biggest fight

image.altText: Michelle Vearing stands hold onto a wire fence in front of Lake Wyangan in Grifftih.

items.synopsis: Cases of motor neurone disease have surged by more than 250 per cent in the past 30 years, and advocates are calling for more research funding to find out why.

title.children: Michelle will not visit a lake where she once spent every weekend, as fears grow it could be leading to a cluster of MND

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Three years ago, Qantas A380 planes were gathering dust with the national carrier on the brink of bankruptcy. Today, the airline has unveiled a record profit of $2.47 billion before tax, fuelled by sky-high demand for domestic and international travel.

title.children: 'What money do we pay back exactly?' Qantas CEO Alan Joyce rules out paying back COVID 'bailout'

image.altText: A composite image of close-ups of Vladimir Putin and Yevgeny Prigozhin.

items.synopsis: Was the demise of a Russian private jet a mafia-style hit orchestrated by Vladimir Putin against Wagner chief Yevgeny Prigozhin or an accident? Let's go over what we know, writes John Lyons.

title.children: Deadly retribution or a convenient accident? Either way, two more of Putin's enemies appear to be dead

image.altText: Jarome Luai is helped off the field

items.synopsis: Panthers five-eighth Jarome Luai dislocates his shoulder, making him a doubt just two weeks out from the start of the NRL finals, as the Eels secure victory in Penrith.

title.children: Panthers suffer major injury blow on eve of NRL finals in 'embarrassing' defeat to Eels

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the prime minister's courtyard

items.synopsis: The Australian Electoral Commission has said ticks would likely be counted as Yes votes, while a cross would likely not be counted, a decision that has attracted the ire of the federal Coalition.

title.children: 'Just stinks': Dutton to complain to AEC about tick and cross Voice referendum voting

image.altText: Palm trees and white sand with blue water

items.synopsis: The well-known tourist destination of South Molle island could soon have a new owner as it becomes the latest Great Barrier Reef island to come up for sale after Lindeman Island, Hook Island, Dunk Island and Long Island.

title.children: Ever wanted to buy a Whitsunday island? This former resort has hit the market

image.altText: Close-up of statue of William Crowther, Tasmanian Premier 1878-1879.

items.synopsis: A statue honouring a former premier who mutilated the body of an Aboriginal man will be taken down in recognition of the hurt he caused Tasmania's Aboriginal community — with advocates saying they hope it is not the last.

title.children: 'A reckoning that's time has come': First colonial-era Australian statue to be torn down

image.altText: Multiple teenage boys crouch inside a cable car dangling at an angle above a forest.

items.synopsis: Children trapped in a cable car dangling from a broken zip-line believed they would never see their families again. Now Pakistan is celebrating a 15-hour-long rescue attempt.

title.children: New footage shows how teens in Pakistan survived marathon cable car ordeal

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: Luis Rubiales created controversy following Spain's 1-0 win over England in the final, when he kissed Jenni Hermoso as she received her winner's medal.

title.children: FIFA opens disciplinary proceedings over World Cup podium kiss

image.altText: Three women speaking with news microphones in front of them.

items.synopsis: After former Melbourne school principal Malka Leifer was sentenced to 15 years in prison for sexually abusing two students in her care, one victim told reporters outside court of the "lifelong" effects of the offending.

title.children: Malka Leifer handed 15-year prison sentence for sexual abuse of 'very vulnerable' former students

image.altText: Wollongong courthouse.

items.synopsis: A Wollongong man sentenced for possessing thousands of files of child abuse material, including images of babies, wipes tears from his eyes as details of the explicit content are revealed in court.

title.children: 'Callous and predatory' man jailed over possession of 90,000 child abuse files

image.altText: Two people wearing hooded jumpers leading another man by the arm from a white van towards a building

items.synopsis: A Moscow court has ruled to extend Gershkovich's arrest until the end of November as he faces a trial for espionage charges.

title.children: US journalist's detention in Russia extended for another three months

image.altText: A man in a suit raises his hands and gives two peace signs

items.synopsis: At the first Republican presidential debate of the 2024 campaign, Donald Trump was nowhere to be found. The frontrunner for the nomination was instead hosting a rival event on Twitter.

title.children: With Donald Trump refusing to debate his Republican rivals, a young millionaire dominated the stage

image.altText: The smoking wreckage of a jet with firefighters standing around it

items.synopsis: Russian authorities say Wagner's Yevgeny Prigozhin was on board a plane that crashed north of Moscow. Here is what you need to know.

title.children: Yevgeny Prigozhin listed among passengers, Wagner pays tribute to leader: What we know about the fatal plane crash

image.altText: A black and white photo of Richard Johnson who was killed in Alexandria Park in 1990

items.synopsis: Richard Johnson was beaten to death by a group of teenagers who lured him to the known gay beat in Alexandria a year after another man was fatally bashed at the same site.

title.children: Sydney murders might have been avoided if police more willing to investigate toilet block bashing, inquiry told

image.altText: A group of feral pigs

items.synopsis: Authorities have killed more than 80 feral pigs in 18 months on SA's Limestone Coast, with authorities saying they were let go by the public.

title.children: Feral pigs 'deliberately and illegally released' across South Australia

image.altText: An aerial view shows the storage tanks for treated water and an opening onto an expanse of water.

items.synopsis: Japan has begun to discharge treated nuclear wastewater from the Fukushima power plant more than a decade after the disaster. Experts say the process is safe, but Pacific activists want the UN to intervene.

title.children: Japan releases treated nuclear wastewater into the Pacific Ocean, as activists make last-ditch call for UN intervention

image.altText: Sliding glass doors into a building with the words Reserve Bank of Australia written above.

items.synopsis: Reserve Bank staff have rejected a 10.5 per cent pay increase, saying it doesn't stop their real wages declining.

title.children: Reserve Bank staff reject 10.5 per cent payrise offer, say it doesn't address cost of living

image.altText: Three police officers in bright yellow hazmat suits

items.synopsis: Police allege they found 10 kilograms of MDMA, 20 litres of MDMA oil and manufacturing equipment during a raid on a Currumbin Valley property.

title.children: Father and son charged over Queensland's largest-ever MDMA lab

image.altText: A varroa mite on a honey bee

items.synopsis: A varroa mite detection in a 'blue zone' during the peak almond season has sent pollination-reliant industries into damage control.

title.children: 'This is our greatest fear': New varroa mite detection in high risk area 'worst case scenario' for NSW bee industry

image.altText: A man and woman stand in a park with a dirt track and house behind them.

items.synopsis: Qantas has reported a mammoth $1.7 billion profit after years of COVID-induced turbulence, but once-loyal customers say the airline's recent actions put it at odds with its 'Spirit of Australia' motto.

title.children: 'You're not the airline that you used to be': Qantas customers left out-of-pocket despite bumper profit results

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith arrives at court

items.synopsis: The war veteran's appeal following his loss in a landmark defamation case came before Justice Nye Perram for the first time on Thursday.

title.children: 'Ugly' safes, drones and closed blinds: Logistics of Roberts-Smith's defamation appeal confirmed

image.altText: man sitting wipe his eyelid

items.synopsis: The Kansas serial killer, who nicknamed himself after "bind, torture, kill", has been linked to at least two cold cases after new leads emerged.

title.children: Killer BTK murdered 10 people. Now he is the 'prime suspect' in more unsolved cases

image.altText: Young Kaius

items.synopsis: Park director Chad Staples has hand-raised a lion cub and a gorilla baby, and now he's an empty-nester after watching his primate friend graduate back to the troop.

title.children: Hand-raised gorilla Kaius reunited with primate family at Mogo Wildlife Park
